channel.title: IPv6 support?
channel.description:
Does anyone here have native IPv6 support? You can test it by going to the following website:
http://whatismyv6.com/
If you have native IPv6 support, or you know an ISP in your area that does, I would like to know. I'm considering enabling IPv6 to access this website, but it would take a lot of modifications (mainly in SMF) to accomplish this, and I'm not sure if it would be worth it, especially if no one would use it.
If you don't know what IPv6 is, click one of these: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ipv6 http://www.google.com/intl/en/ipv6/

item.title: IPv6 support?
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:26, topic:375723”][quote author=sppt link=topic=471651.msg3554276#msg3554276 date=1301770497]

You are connecting with an IPv4 Address of:

Hmm so in english what is the the difference. Try to make it a one sentence/word answer. Faster?

Sorry for my lack of knowledge. Just trying to learn.

More capacity.
If I recall correctly, with IPv6, the amount of ips assignable to a single person is as much ips as there are in IPv4.
[/quote]
Wrong.
Every person could get 4.8 * 10^28 IP addresses.
Math: (2^128) / 7000000000[/quote]
Oh well.
They’re both huge enough to pretty much ensure we’ll never run out.

Read full topic

item.title: IPv6 support?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

The Internet Protocol version 4, or IPv4, is the defined standard in the world today, but it is being replaced by the more advanced IPv6, to help solve the IP address exhaustion problem that is looming on the horizon. IPv4 uses 32 bits to define each address, which, in total, is roughly four billion addresses. This was a huge number during its inception, but with the internet boom, this address pool is expected to run-out in 2010 or 2011. IPv6 uses 128 bits for each address.

Read full topic

item.title: IPv6 support?
item.dc:creator: @Saphire1 Saphire`
item.description:
@Saphire1 wrote:

Q: What is World IPv6 Day? This is a trial period where a number of major web sites will provide their content on both IPv4 and IPv6. This is being led by the Internet Society (ISOC). more information is posted on their World IPv6 Day page.

World IPv6 day, scheduled for 8 June 2011, is a global-scale test flight of IPv6 sponsored by the Internet Society. On World IPv6 Day, major web companies and other industry players will come together to enable IPv6 on their main websites for 24 hours. The goal is to motivate organizations across the industry – Internet service providers, hardware makers, operating system vendors and web companies – to prepare their services for IPv6 to ensure a successful transition as IPv4 address space runs out.

Read full topic

item.title: IPv6 support?
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

zachera:

Interesting topic sorry to bump, but FYI a lot of ISPs were “pushed” by the final IP allocations a few months ago and are now preparing, but as for productive use, its probably going to be a few years before they start flipping switches as I’ve read. It’ll be one of those major impact events similar to the Y2K bug where nobody cared and ended up learning about it the hard way.

my memory may be hazy but everyone was in a panic over the Y2K scare(I was 12 at the time seem to remember theFOX news hyping it up)? it seems to be the opposite with the IPv6 transition.

Read full topic

item.title: IPv6 support?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

My ISP (UPC) is preparing it’s network, or at least they say they do. They expect to switch to IPv6 somewhere in 2011. We do have a task-force IPv6, among the participants are 3 government department’s. Odd thing is that my ISP isn’t participating.

Let me know when they do actually go live with IPv6 support in this thread please.

The US government has a mandate that all government organizations must support IPv6 very soon (I can’t recall the date). Doesn’t apply to ISPs and the like though.

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:13, topic:375723”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=471651.msg3450199#msg3450199 date=1293685957]
So seriously no one has native ipv6? I was hoping one of those tiny advanced european countries would at least.
[/quote]
There is a very simple reason for that. If ipv6 cost them money, and they don’t earn anything on it, its bad business.

Anyway, if you didn’t know, some users may not be able to connect your website at all, a Norwegian newspaper added IPv6 support and 0.04% where not able to connect, not much but the number may be higher in countries with 2nd world Internet.

Speaking of tiny advanced European countries, Russia was best with IPv6 in 2008 according to Google.[/quote]

Maybe right now it isn’t costing them money. But within the next few years when they run out of IPv4 addresses and can’t add any new customers and their current customers can’t access most of the net, it will certainly be costing them money, a LOT of money.

Also, I know all about the problems regarding bad routes and being able to resolve an IPv6 IP while not being able to connect to it, to combat this I was going to simply ‘pull a google’ and not set an AAAA record for www., instead only setting one for ipv6.moparisthebest.com and the like. That way only people who want to connect via IPv6 will connect that way. At least during the transitioning phase until IPv6 is more widespread.

edit:
Actually, google, facebook, and many other sites do it this exact way. They have a different URL for IPv6.

Read full topic

item.title: IPv6 support?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I think the Australian ISP Internode has either introduced or is going to introduce IPv6. No other ISPs in Australia have it as far as I’m aware though, so don’t count on any users from down in Australia making use of it.

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I talked to a senior level tech at my ISP (Time Warner, roadrunner) about it, and he said they have no plans to ever support it in the future. When I asked about alternative plans they had for IPv4 addresses running out in the near future, he said they had no plan whatsoever. Glad to see they are on top of things… :rolleyes:

item.title: IPv6 support?
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

I know a pretty major ISP in the Netherlands refuses to enable IPV6, they don’t seem to get the point of it.
In fact, the default routers they deliver block all ipv6 traffic.
